newsitem.title: GERMANY: Deutsche plans to reduce German holdings.
newsitem.headline: Deutsche plans to reduce German holdings.

text.p: Deutsche Bank AG's new chief executive Rolf Breuer was quoted on Tuesday as saying he plans to reduce the bank's industrial holdings in German companies in a bid to achieve a balance between its domestic and international holdings.

Breuer, who takes over as chief executive after Deutsche's annual shareholders' meeting on Tuesday, was quoted as telling the Financial Times in an interview that there could eventually be a 50-50 balance between holdings in German companies and those held abroad.
But he added this would probably not happen until the next century and depended on how quickly taxes would be cut.
"We are a Eruopean bank, we want to be the number one bank in Europe and in the euro, and we basically have a portfolio of only German industrial holdings," Breuer said.
"I have always said we want to Europeanise, if not internationalise our portfolio."
Deutsche's holdings in German industrial companies include a 22.6 percent stake in Daimler-Benz AG and 10 percent in insurer Allianz AG Holding AG.
Its stakes also include 25.8 percent of Philip Holzmann AG, Deutz AG, 10 percent of Munich Reinsurance and 10.2 percent of Continental AG.
Breuer also said that international diversification of its holdings would provide more shareholder value for investors, the paper said.
